These changes also increase the amount the council can authorise from $1,000 to $100,000. Currently the council has a budget of over $1 million, with enormous responsibilities, including providing housing, sewerage and roads to the community. The coalition has agreed to the legislative change because it believes that it would be unworkable to have a limit of $1,000 before ministerial approval is needed, not to mention a great deal of paternalism. This figure is acceptable, as it follows other examples such as Tiwi Bathurst and Melville islands and the central and northern land councils.

The changes also provide for a provision, when there is no quorum, for AGMs to be recalled with a lower quorum at a later date. I understand the council has had difficulty in getting the size of quorum it needed for its AGMs and what we have here would appear to be a rolling system of AGMs which keep going until there are actually the numbers that are required.

The changes alter the term of an executive from one year to two. Although I must admit this is not a major issue, I did have some concerns about it but was convinced by the council that it was important for them to actually get work done and not to face election every year, and it enables the council to make by-laws which can be disallowed by either house of parliament. This power to make by-laws allows the council to act similarly to any local council. The community council will then be able to act for the benefit of the community in relation to housing, education and health. The council will be able to prioritise its needs to best suit the interests and wellbeing of the community. These by-laws will help protect and preserve the cultural, sacred and environmental needs of the community and the land.

Under the lease agreement the current rights of leaseholders are preserved and unaffected by this claim, while the rights of other residents, including those stationed on the naval base at Jervis Bay, are preserved by the Commonwealth. The coalition has consulted widely on this matter to ensure that all parties agree with the land claim and the lease-back arrangements.

For the readers of Hansard, I would like to mention that Jervis Bay is located on the south coast of New South Wales, 160 kilometres from Sydney and 130 kilometres east of Canberra. We do tend to presume in this place that everybody is familiar with the areas we are talking about, but I know that my constituents in South Australia would not be familiar with the region. Apparently 85 per cent of the territory has been declared national park, while a separate area of just over 400 hectares is Aboriginal land under the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986. The remaining land is set aside for a naval base and private leasehold land.

The Jervis Bay territory was acquired by the Commonwealth from New South Wales in 1915 under the Jervis Bay Territory Acceptance Act in accordance with the Seat of Government Act 1908. For more than 20,000 years Jervis Bay has been occupied by Aboriginal people. I am very curious about this figure of 20,000 as I am aware Aboriginal history in this country goes back 40,000 years, so I wonder whether this figure is not wrong and whether indeed, rather than 20,000 years, that should read 40,000. But at the moment the figure I have before me is 20,000 years.

The Wreck Bay community comprises descendants of seven language groups on the south coast region of New South Wales. They are traditionally fishing people who, until the late 1980s, operated a fleet of net fishing boats. Overfishing of the area by commercial operators has diminished the fish supply in the area; however, a community member has retained a commercial fishing licence and a number of the people in the community supplement their diet and income by fishing. At present there are approximately 200 members of the Wreck Bay community.

The Jervis Bay Botanic Gardens were opened in 1974 as an extension to Canberra's National Botanic Gardens, and the Jervis Bay National Park was opened in March 1992. The Wreck Bay Aboriginal community has had an informal reserve status for most of the century. An area of land for the community was formally gazetted in 1950, and in 1965 the control of Wreck Bay was transferred from the New South Wales Aboriginal Protection Board to the Commonwealth Department of the Interior.

In 1971 the Jervis Bay Nature Reserve was proclaimed over the majority of the Jervis Bay Territory and in 1986 just over 400 hectares of freehold land was granted to the Wreck Bay community under the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act. As a result of that act the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council was formed to administer the land in the best interests of the community.

The coalition has consulted with the Shoalhaven council, which supports the agreement and hopes that tourism can be boosted in the Shoalhaven area by having an indigenous theme in the national park. At present $300 million is generated through tourism in the Shoalhaven district, making it the second largest industry.

The Wreck Bay council currently runs a business enterprise named `Walkabouts', which caters for groups who want to learn about the history, culture and traditions of the Wreck Bay community. Four types of tours are offered under Walkabouts: fishing history, campfire talks, bush tucker, and bush medicine and animal spotlight walks.

The joint management of Jervis Bay National Park is a positive recognition of the Wreck Bay community's lengthy association with the land and waters within the Jervis Bay Territory. The coalition and the Wreck Bay community believe that the joint management arrangements will preserve the culture and traditions of the community, protect that community's traditional rights, secure an economic base to develop the Wreck Bay community and enable it to ultimately become self-sufficient and provide employment and training opportunities for all members of the community.

The employment and training of Aboriginal people is vital. They remain the most disadvantaged group in Australia's labour market, and it has been distressing to see that over the last five years we have actually seen an eight per cent drop in employment amongst Aboriginal people or, to phrase it more correctly, there has been an eight per cent increase in unemployment amongst Aboriginal people. I understand, from my consultation with the Wreck Bay community, that several community members already work in the national park and that, following the handover of land, additional strategies will be in place to train and employ further Aboriginal people in park management.

The enthusiasm of the Wreck Bay community to participate in the joint management of lands is commendable. This bill goes a long way towards the reconciliation process, which we must all acknowledge has been—and will continue to be—a difficult one for Aboriginal people. All members I think would like to see more of these types of agreements, which will hasten that reconciliation process, not just for the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community but for all Aboriginal communities.

I also mention that this bill makes an amendment to the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 to enable the commission to inquire into—and report to the minister on—the granting of financial assistance for the financing of works and services in certain Australian territories. The coalition has consulted with the Norfolk Island government, which has said that it has no problem with this amendment.

I conclude by congratulating the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community and the Aboriginal community council. This bill acknowledges the importance of Jervis Bay to that community and recognises its excellent work and commitment to providing a sound future for its community members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Gibson) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to say a few words today, it has been rather fascinating to see the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan) in the House making what I consider to be a rather pathetic and hypocritical effort to pull the banks into order. Having said that, and in fairness to him, at least he has had the courage to attempt to do something—he is one of the few people in this place. It amazes me that there is such pressure on people who have come from a state house to conform. John Pilger coined the important phrase `the secret country'; this is a similar phrase to Donald Horne's phrase `the lucky country'. They should become part of the Australian lexicon. It is remarkable that this country is still able to work as a democracy in the light of its primitive, antiquated, defamation laws. If honourable members have ever stuck their necks out on odd occasions as I have, they would have realised that the protection afforded to them by the House is negligible and that is why the scene was set in Australia for the great tragedy of the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: We went into the 1980s with an annual bankruptcy rate of about 4,000 people: about 4,000 people were going bankrupt every year in Australia. In the golden period of Australia, the late John McEwen's period in Australian history, in the late 1960s and early 1970s, there were 2,000 bankruptcies a year. There was 1.5 per cent unemployment. We had the highest wages of any country in the world, the highest growth in wages anywhere in the world and the highest growth in population possibly anywhere in the world. We were the golden country in the golden age and we were quite rightly called `the lucky country' in those days.

There were 2,000 bankruptcies a year at that time and there were 4,000 when Mr Keating and Mr Hawke were elected. Within a period of about six years, through such brilliant initiatives as the deregulation of the banks, there was a complete reversal. When I voted against the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, three Labor staffers from this place rang me. They said that the only person to vote against the sale was a Tory. They said that this was at the very heart of their Labor beliefs. There was nothing more at the heart of Labor belief than the ownership of the Commonwealth Bank and the control and sovereignty of our nation's financial institutions. Without the Commonwealth bank, as far as I am concerned and as far as many Australians are concerned, the right to that sovereignty has been eroded and may be eroded to such an extent that it no longer substantially exists.

In the 1980s, we went from 4,000 bankruptcies per year fairly swiftly; in about five or six years, we were hitting 15,000 bankruptcies per year—it might have been within seven or eight years—and we have stayed at that figure. In fact, the last quarterly figures still seemed to be looking at an average annual rate of 15,000. For every bankruptcy that occurs, the economists tell us that there are 20 businesses that go broke.

In fact, I know very few people who have taken technical bankruptcy. I would probably only be able to name about four or five. If you were to ask me how many people I know who have gone broke, I would just go through everybody I know. It is very hard to find a business that is trading successfully these days. If we are talking about even a 10-figure number, that is 150,000 Australian families who go broke every single year. To sheet it home to where this came from, people borrowed money at the end of the 1970s and at the start of the 1980s at an 8 1/2 per cent interest rate. These people worked out, as a lot of people did—as I most certainly did—that maybe the interest rates could go to 12 per cent.

All I can say from personal experience is that, in our last year on our station property, which was our business, we were paying 29 per cent interest rates. What happens is, of course, that you get pushed into overdraft because you cannot meet the interest payments, and the overdraft rates contain a punitive charge. It always amazes me that, with the banks, when you are in trouble and you need a bit of assistance they go the other way. They bung an extra four or five per cent upon you because you are in a danger zone. That took us to the ridiculous figure of 29 per cent.

To some degree, I praise the member for Lilley for at least having the courage to say something. But it amazes me that he would tinker around the edges and talk about bank charges, when the banks have for almost a decade taken 15 per cent interest rates to which they were not even remotely entitled. I walked into the bank in the period when people were paying 15 and 17 per cent interest rates and, if you lodged money with the banks, you could get 6 1/2 per cent. We had from the banks the highest split of any country on earth between investment moneys and lending moneys, and this was allowed to continue for 10 years.

The reason it was allowed to continue was that the deregulation of the banks enabled a whole lot of charlatans to profit in this country—the corporate cowboys or `bold riders', as Trevor Sykes called them in his book of the same name, which is one of the great books that people should read. To understand what happened in Australia in the 1980s and the 1990s, you must read that book. He names 16 men in Australia who got away with $17,000 million. They were lent that money by the banks, entirely unsecured. When the banks went to foreclose, they foreclosed on nothing. All of the cargo containers were empty. All of the assets were gone, stripped away from the company.

Take the case of Robert Holmes a Court's company. He must rank as one of the great success stories of the corporate cowboys in Australia. He sold his company for $360 million. When the taxpayers of Western Australia tried to get the assets out of that company, which was then owned by Alan Bond, there were no assets there at all. The whole $360 million was gone. A delightful article in the Business Review Weekly, referring to Janet Holmes a Court, said the figure of $360 million was wildly exaggerated, and that it was only $160 million that the taxpayers had lost. Only $160 million: that was all. Of course, this person is very friendly with people in positions of power here in Canberra.

Such people—and Sykes designates some 21 of them—were able to get away with $17,000 million. Further on in The bold riders, Sykes said that in a very short period of time the banks lost to such people a figure in excess of $28,000 million. These were substantiated figures. He gives the details of the figures in the book. When the banks lost all that money, they had to get it back from somebody, but they had not been quite so reckless with the small business, the owner-operator, the family business and the farmer in Australia. Oh, no! The banks had those loans secured, all right. They had the securities over people's own houses, so such people lost not only their businesses but also their homes.

Not only did these people lose their businesses and their homes but also, when they walked away, because they had great pride, honesty and decency, they did not take bankruptcy. They walked away with debts hanging over their shoulders of $50,000 or $100,000 or, in some cases, $200,000. These courageous Australians have worked tenaciously to try and work their debt off—which is, of course, entirely impossible: they will carry that debt for the rest of their days. If they have a windfall later on somewhere down the track, the bank can come back and take everything away from them once again. So their lives are wrecked, ruined and destroyed.

We are talking about 150,000 Australian families per year for the period of the seven or eight years in which this has been going on. We are talking about a million families in Australia that have been utterly and completely destroyed by the deregulation of the banks. After this wonderful success story, once we had proved how successful the deregulation of the banks had been, we then proceeded to deregulate all the other parts of the Australian economy. Having proved that this is such a marvellous success, we will then proceed to deregulate all the other parts of the Australian economy.

As for the levers of power, the Reserve Bank is still there. But, whilst the Reserve Bank has a very effective mechanism for pushing interest rates up, its mechanism for pushing interest rates down is very ineffective. I have not got time to go into that here today. So there are imperfections in that system. The other mechanism that was desperately needed was the Commonwealth Bank.

A great line of Australian heroes have walked through this parliament. I do not hesitate to name King O'Malley. Ted Theodore, for all of his shortcomings, gave his political life entirely, as did King O'Malley. Ben Chifley did, as well. They were all Labor men. Every single one of them gave his political life in fighting international financiers who used this country as a playground. We had by far the worst depression anywhere in the world. In Theodore's case, it was his own party that destroyed him. They listened to Sir Neimeyer from the Bank of England. They chose to listen to him rather than their own Treasurer, Mr Theodore.

I might say that John McEwen most certainly was in exactly the same mould, as he dominated the Australian economy for 10 years. Most certainly, we had the banks up against the wall and we were giving the orders, not the banks. When that situation was completely destroyed by the deregulatory policies of the incoming Labor government in the early 1980s, we went into a situation of absolute disaster, exactly as we did in the Great Depression in Australia when Theodore's advice was ignored. Once again, we listened to the banks, as we are doing here today, and fiddled around on the edges.

I do not want to condemn the member for Lilley, because I think that at least he has shown some sort of courage, but fiddling around on the edges talking about bank charges is quite ludicrous. When our farmers have to pay 11 1/2 per cent for their interest rates, our small businessmen have to pay 11 1/2 per cent for their interest rates and our manufacturers have to pay 11 1/2 per cent for their interest rates while our American competitors are paying six per cent and our Japanese competitors are paying 3 1/2 per cent, it is quite ludicrous to start talking and fiddling around with some absolutely, ridiculously irrelevant bank charges. Giving away the mechanisms that we needed to control the banks is something for which history will condemn the Labor government of the 1980s right into the future.

In the final minutes that I have available to me I want to tell you what is happing out there on the ground. Cattle are no longer being inoculated for botulism, so they die. Calves are no longer being weaned off their mothers, so both die. This nation's fifth greatest asset is its cattle herd. One third of it has gone: it no longer exists. It will continue to decline. There will be swings up and swings down, but the long-term trend will be one of decline.

The nation's greatest asset is our sheep herd. Right throughout Australian history—until the minimum price scheme, under these great deregulation policies, was removed—sheep were the biggest export earning item in the Australian economy. The nation's greatest asset—greater than coal and greater than gold—is our sheep herd. One-third of our sheep herd has gone, and the herd will continue to go. We have demolished one-third of the nation's greatest asset and one-third of the nation's fifth greatest asset.

Let me put the human perspective on it. Those people out there are sheepmen and cattlemen. It is more visible with them; small business throughout Australia is suffering in exactly the same way. The president of the Cattlemen's Union in Charters Towers was being leaned on by the banks and had a drought raging at the same time. After he had shot some of his cattle, because he could not afford to keep them alive—he had to shoot the calves, because they would have killed their mothers, as well—he proceeded to put a gun in his mouth and blow his own brains out. He killed himself.

Similarly, on the outskirts of Rockhampton there was a farmer from a third-generation farming family who said, `The banks are not going to take my station off my family. We came here when there was no-one living in this country and we took this up. We dug the holes that produced the water. We built the fences. We looked after the cattle. We created this great asset for Australia, and we are not giving it to the banks, which have robbed and thieved off all of us throughout the last decade.' Before the banks foreclosed on him, he proceeded to pour petrol all around the homestead, set it alight and burn himself to death.
That is what is happening out there every day of the week. Women are crying, hearts are broken and people are going off their heads with worry. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments this morning on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration report. This report reviews the 1993-94 annual report of the Reserve Bank and the 1993-94 annual report of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, and I speak as a member of the committee.

PARA.TAB: I would like to start by making some very brief remarks about the member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite), who is a longstanding member of the committee. I have been a member of the committee since my election and Mr Braithwaite seems to have been a member of the committee forever. This is his last term and—I echo the comments of the member for Chifley (Mr Price)—the member for Dawson can be rightly proud of the contribution he has made to the parliamentary scrutiny of this area of policy. The member for Dawson is a member whom I hold in high regard, he is a member of great integrity, and his departure will be a loss to the committee and the parliament.

There are three issues that I will comment on this morning, two of which are raised directly by the committee's report and one which I will take the opportunity to mention in passing. The first relates to the question of derivatives, the second relates to the question of bank fees and charges, and the third relates to regional banking, which is a matter of some interest to me as a member from Western Australia where, in recent days, we have seen the Trade Practices Commission approve the takeover of Challenge Bank by Westpac and the announcement by the state Liberal government of the sale of the state bank, Bankwest—the old R&I—to the Bank of Scotland.

I comment firstly about derivatives. I mentioned that the committee's report reviews not only the Reserve Bank's annual report for 1993-94 but also the ISC's annual report. That arises as a direct result of concern to ensure that, after the Baring Brothers crash earlier this year, systems were in place in Australia to ensure that a crash of a similar nature could not occur here or at least that the risks of that were minimised. In respect of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the committee has formally recommended that the Treasurer monitor the implementation of the ISC's proposal for the use of derivatives by superannuation funds and report to parliament on progress at the first opportunity in 1996. That recommendation arises as a result of some concern on the part of the committee that the regulation of derivatives in the insurance and superannuation area is not as rigorous as it is so far as the banks are concerned under the supervision of the RBA.

I will comment on the good news before the bad news and deal with the review that the committee conducted so far as banks' handling of derivatives is concerned. The report outlines that, after the Baring Brothers crash, the committee resolved to establish a subcommittee—which I chaired and which the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and the member for Dawson were members of—to conduct public hearings with both the Reserve Bank and the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in respect of derivatives.

I think the reason I drew the short straw to chair the subcommittee was that I also chair the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, which has been very active in this area following the Barings crash. In recent months, that committee has conducted public hearings with the Australian Stock Exchange, the Sydney Futures Exchange, the Australian Securities Commission and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. I am expecting that it will be able to report to both houses of parliament in the course of October or November of this year and complement the report which the House of Representatives banking committee has made in this area in respect of RBA supervision and supervision by the ISC of the use of derivatives.

I think it is true to say, and it is reflected by the committee's report, that at the public hearing members of the subcommittee were entirely satisfied that the Reserve Bank had these matters in hand or under control, but that that same confidence was not expressed or held by the subcommittee after its public hearing with the ISC. I now refer to a number of paragraphs in the committee's report which I think highlight that sentiment. The committee's report on derivatives is found at chapter 3. Paragraph 3.5 gives an indication as to the nature and use of derivatives and says:

SPEECH.PARA: Derivatives are instruments which are used primarily to manage risk, they are a form of insurance against adverse movements in market prices. The demand for risk-management instruments by both financial institutions and corporate users has led to the development of more complex derivative products. The high notional principal values involved, together with the potential for volatility, has resulted in public disquiet over the use of derivatives.

Under the heading `Risk management', the committee's report refers to the steps that the Reserve Bank has in place to ensure that banks have reasonable controls in place in respect of derivative activity. Paragraph 3.15, where the committee is referring to a survey conducted by the Reserve Bank, says:

Following the survey, the Reserve Bank was satisfied that banks had reasonable controls in place to manage derivatives activities, but that further work would continue in direct discussion with individual banks. A program of visits to banks commenced in late 1994. The purpose of the visits was to review banks' derivatives activities and risk management. The Bank set a number of objectives for the visits program: to increase understanding of how banks managed the risks associated with derivatives; to provide a greater insight into the models used by banks to measure their exposure to risk; and to require corrective action if deficiencies were found in those models. The Reserve Bank is focussing the visits on those banks which account for the bulk of derivatives business in Australia and expects to have visited about 20 banks by the end of this year.
At paragraphs 3.21 and 3.22, the committee states:

The main risk for a bank is a loss associated with the failure of a customer and exposures to individual customers are monitored closely by banks. Many of the well publicised cases of derivatives losses in recent years have been among companies (Barings being the exception) which have not posed a threat to the financial system as a whole. The RBA also made the point that while derivatives markets can be volatile, trading in these markets is tightly controlled by the Futures Exchange with strict rules for lodgement of margins and for "circuit breakers" in trading . . .

3.22 The RBA also pointed out that despite recent shocks such as the share market crash in 1987, the fall in bond prices in 1994 and the recent collapse of Barings, the financial markets have held up well and that derivatives have in fact caused fewer problems for banks than some normal businesses such as lending for commercial property.
Those comments from the RBA and the committee put the issue of systemic risk in context. At the end of chapter 3—at 3.45—the report concludes:

The Committee is satisfied that the Reserve Bank has adopted a responsible and thorough approach in dealing with the potential risk that derivatives could pose to the stability of the financial system. The Committee also acknowledges that this process is on-going and that it is essential that the supervisory response continues to evolve to meet the change in nature and growing use of derivatives instruments.

I think that is an accurate reflection of the views of the subcommittee, which were formulated following the public hearing with the Reserve Bank. As I have indicated, that same degree of confidence is not displayed in respect of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, and this is an area of some concern.

PARA.TAB: The committee's comments in paragraph 3.46 stand in stark contrast to the attitude that the committee takes in respect of the RBA. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Supervision of the banking industry is much more detailed than that of the insurance and superannuation industries. While the Committee endorses the approach of the ISC, the regulatory regime with regard to superannuation and insurance is still being formulated. The growing importance of superannuation requires that the ISC ensure that the process initiated with the release of the discussion papers be advanced as a matter of priority. The Committee was particularly concerned at the lack of data available on the use of derivatives by superannuation funds and will consider further examining the ISC's progress in this matter when it receives the ISC's 1994-95 annual report.

My personal view, which is not necessarily shared by the committee—I know it is shared by the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) and he will not mind if I volunteer it for him—is that that process is absolutely essential and that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration needs to be paying assiduous attention to the initiatives of the ISC in this area to ensure that in the area of superannuation the same high standard is met, so far as risk management regimes are concerned, as we find in respect of the banks and the Reserve Bank. Those comments of concern by the committee are best found in paragraph 3.37 of the committee's report which states:

The Committee is concerned at the lack of knowledge about the use of derivatives in the superannuation industry in particular. The ISC advised that `the use of derivatives by life insurance companies, superannuation funds and general insurance companies in an overall context is relatively small. Apart from a general feeling, I cannot give you any further guidance.'

The committee was not satisfied that a general feeling which could not give further guidance was a satisfactory response where the management of insurance and superannuation funds is concerned. At paragraph 3.39 the committee reports:
. . . the ISC should place a high priority on finalising the new regulatory approach for the use of derivatives by superannuation funds.
Those concerns and comments led to the committee's formal recommendation that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) report to parliament on these improvements.

PARA.TAB: I move from the area of derivatives to make some brief comments on bank fees and charges. The committee's report makes it clear that, as a result of the review into bank fees and charges by the PSA, the committee would not delve into that area in any great length or at all. I draw to the attention of the committee what I regard as the most important paragraph in the Prices Surveillance Authority report on bank fees and charges, which is found on page 28 of the executive summary and recommendations, where the following comment is made:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall, the Authority is confident that market processes will deliver appropriate outcomes for consumers. If ready access to RTAs is not maintained in the future, however, it will be necessary for Government to act because ready access is a necessary part of modern-day living. Whilst a regulated basic banking product is not necessary today, the option remains one for Government to consider in the future if necessary.

What that makes clear, which is the point that the Treasurer (Mr Willis) has recently been making, is that, if the banks do not provide an appropriate and timely response to the PSA report, the banks can expect re-regulation in this area. I have previously complimented the Treasurer on what I regard as his fine work in this area, which stands in stark contrast to comments that have been made by members opposite, particularly by the shadow minister for finance and my colleague from Western Australia, the member for Forrest (Mr Prosser), who has said that there should be no re-regulation in this area.

PARA.TAB: The deputy chair of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, the member for McPherson, Mr Bradford, in the public hearing before the ABA which was part of the committee's work, was absolutely craven in his defence of the banks in this area. He said words to the effect that the antipathy towards the banks on this issue was a considerable overstatement and then gave a craven apology for them. In recent times, the Premier of Western Australia, Richard Court, has publicly indicated that he does not believe re-regulation is appropriate in this area either. That stands in stark contrast to the attitude taken by members on this side of the House and we look forward to timely and appropriate responses to the PSA's report and to the Treasurer's requests.

I will conclude by touching very briefly on the question of regional banking. I was severely disappointed that the government of Western Australia could not find the wit, the wisdom or the capacity to bring about a merger between Challenge Bank and the Bank of Western Australia to ensure a strong regional bank for Western Australia. We now run the grave risk that there will be no effective regional bank in Western Australia, given the takeover of Challenge by Westpac and the wholesale disposal of the Bank of Western Australia to the Bank of Scotland. I regard this as a great lost opportunity which lies at the feet of the state government. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the opportunity to speak to this report. My first comments are in relation to the recommendation that the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration inquire into the effectiveness of alternative dispute resolution between clients and banks. The Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman, Ms Sue Brooks, was appointed in May 1994 and the main office is in Melbourne. The ombudsman deals only with complaints from individuals, and in matters involving sums no greater than $100,000. Those complaints mainly concern errors that the banks have made. Last year there were approximately 30,000 complaints lodged; 10 per cent of those were considered, and of those only 20 to 30 per cent actually went before the ombudsman. The remaining complaints were resolved between the bank and the client.

PARA.TAB: The bank objected to the committee's recommendations that the $100,000 limit be extended to $200,000 and that not only individuals, but small companies, small businesses and farmers be able to lodge complaints to the ombudsman. Such an expansion of the scheme seems to work well overseas. I see no reason why it could not work well here, and I support that recommendation.

Mediation may also be looked at. A farm mediation bill was passed by the previous New South Wales parliament. That bill was a response to the heavy-handed treatment that was being meted out to some farmers, many of whom come from my electorate. Unfortunately there are a number of deficiencies in that state bill. It raised a very high expectation that things would occur which have not yet occurred, although it is too early to fully judge the effectiveness of the bill.

Anecdotal evidence coming into my office suggests that the bill may be more advantageous to the banks than to the farmers who are actually in trouble. I am hearing stories of farmers who have gone through mediation, and who now find that, if they violate any of the agreements that have been put in place at the end of the mediation process, the banks can move immediately to sell them up without any fuss. That was surely not the intention when the bill was introduced.

I recognise that there are farmers who will always be in trouble, even in good seasons and when prices are high. But I am talking about a great percentage of farmers who are now finding themselves in difficulty, largely through circumstances outside their control, such as drought and low commodity prices. In my electorate, banks are selling up what most people would believe to be viable farms, and this is not always in the interests of the banks themselves. These fire sales bring in less money for the banks to repay their debt than they would otherwise receive if they stuck with the farmers for a longer period. Also, if the sales are forced and the prices brought are lower than expected, this collapses the equity for the neighbouring farmers and puts them in trouble with their banks. The banks should be very mindful of these factors.

I have constituents who have been able to meet every interest payment due to the bank and have recommendations from their own rural counsellors stating that theirs are viable farms and should be allowed to continue, yet the banks are moving in and selling them up. I find it quite remarkable that the banks want to do that. Banks are there to make money for their shareholders and they make money, primarily, by lending money to others. If the banks are lending money to farmers and the farmers are meeting the interest payments and have got good prospects of being able to repay the principal in the future, the reason the banks are moving in and selling them up in the way they are is a puzzle indeed.

We have had wool prices come off 20 to 30 per cent over the last couple of months. Cattle prices are down. The outlook for cattle on the American market is very grim, in the short to medium term. We have had recent collapses in wheat and barley prices, particularly in the last season. Overriding all this is one of the worst droughts, if not the worst drought, in Australia's history.

We are distributing food parcels in my electorate. Here we are, in 1995 in an affluent, First World country, and some farmers in my part of the world are surviving, in part, on food parcels. Yet the banks are acting in this fashion. The worst offender—in my area, at least—is the Commonwealth Bank. That is closely followed by the State Bank and, to a lesser extent, Westpac. The ANZ and the National Australia Bank have also been at fault on occasion.

I might just give one example. I had a farming family come to me the other day. In 1989, they owed the bank $1.8 million and were paying $278,000 a year in interest payments. They met those payments. Over the last six years, they have reduced their debt from $1.8 million to $700,000. Their interest payment has fallen to $78,000 a year. So they have been able to reduce their interest payments, they have been able to reduce their principal repayments and they have met every interest payment. Yet the bank has forced them into mediation.

The rural counsellor says they are a good prospect if the bank will only hold off, for a couple of years, on insisting on further principal repayments. In the meantime, of course, they will continue to meet their interest payments. But the bank has forced them into mediation. Why would the bank do this? This happened to be the Commonwealth Bank, which had a notorious manager in the town of Nyngan who went into hotels and clubs and met clients on the footpath of the street, almost forcing loans on these farmers. I fully acknowledge it takes two to tango, but these people were led to believe, with the advice that they were getting, that they could take up these loans and meet the repayments.

What happened, of course, was that those who did take up the loans suddenly found that the interest payments had blown out from of the order of 14 per cent into the 20 per cent levels, and found themselves in difficulty. When this manager was moved on, the bank moved in—in a ruthless fashion, in many instances—on the people who had taken out these loans. This particular family is one case in point. It has been able to meet the principal repayments and the interest payments, yet the bank is forcing it into mediation, at a time when this particular family—living in division A of the Nyngan Rural Lands Protection Board—is surviving through probably close to the worst drought on record.

Another thing I would like to see the committee look at is the penalty rates that banks charge when farmers and small businesses find themselves in difficulty. This is commonly of the order of about 2 1/4 per cent or more. I had an instance recently where a client had an increase in their interest rates of 6 1/4 per cent, because they had moved into a higher risk category. It is somewhat paradoxical, I believe, that the bank charges higher interest rates because they move into a higher risk category. The bank itself adds to that very risk. In fact, the bank almost guarantees that these people will go to the wall. I do not think it is in the bank's interest to be charging such high penalty rates. It guarantees failure, in many instances. I believe this is an area which the committee should look at very closely indeed in its future deliberations.

Another contentious area is fees and charges—probably the worst area, where banks are concerned. Although banks have improved their practices in recent years, people often come to my office with stories about how they have taken out a loan and have asked for the full fees and charges to be disclosed. However, three or six months into their loan, they find that there are other fees and charges that have somehow suddenly crept in. These fees and charges add two, three and four per cent interest to their overall interest payments. I believe that these fees and charges should not be hidden but should be up-front, simple and easily calculated by the people who are taking out the loans. As I say, people come to my office with such stories and complain about these things. I believe that a modern computerised bank should be able to get its act together in this area.

I also believe that there should be better competition between banks. If a small business or a farmer has a loan and gets offered a better rate of interest by another bank or lending institution, they should be able to swap relatively easily and simply, without excessive penalties being put in place. I realise that, if a bank has lent money and if a person wants to withdraw from a loan, some penalty has to be applied. We have heard of cases where three months interest has been charged to transfer a loan from one client to another, when a few hundred dollars would probably suffice in this modern electronic age. Three months interest may have been all very well in the 1920s when interest rates were in the order of four or five per cent. But, today, when they are 10 and 15—and, as they have been in the past, 20 and 25—per cent, three months interest means that you cannot swap your loan from one bank to another even though it might be offering two or three per cent less, because, by the time you have paid the penalty, this has, in effect, eliminated all competition.

I also have some concern with the deals that the banks are doing with some farmers. I believe that the way in which banks operate with farmers and small business should be open and above board, and the same rules should apply to all players in the same circumstances. But, in case after case, people tell me that they have gone to their bank and asked for the best deal possible for their circumstances. They have been given a deal by the bank. They have then gone out and spoken to another farmer or small business person who has got a better deal at another bank. These people then go back to their original bank and say, `Hey, my neighbour has got this deal at two per cent less' or whatever, and the bank immediately comes to the party and offers them the same deal. If they had not talked to the other person, they would not have learnt of that. An extra two or three per cent off your loan is very significant in these hard times. The criteria should be spelt out and should be much more visible than they presently are.

I find that banks are writing off large amounts of money for some clients who are in difficulty, simply because they are very vocal in the community, whereas other clients who have done the right thing by dealing honestly and openly with their bank do not get the same deal, even though they are in a better financial position. The people who have been getting these large write-offs are sworn to secrecy, so there is no openness about it. In these times, when the rural community is suffering enough, it is not a healthy situation to have these whispering campaigns and to have one neighbour being played off against another neighbour. I would like to think that the banks would consider that, when they are dealing with clients in the future. I see it constantly: it is not an infrequent thing; it is happening all the time. I am not one who comes in here to bash banks: I believe banks have served this country well; they have served their clients well.

I am not one who would deny banks a profit. I do not get twitchy when banks make a profit; I get alarmed when they make losses. That aside, many practices seem to be creeping into the way in which banks deal with their clients, and they are causing a lot of dissension. I believe that people have legitimate complaints about banks in this regard and that it is actually in the interests of the banks to get their house in order in this area, to be more visible and up-front, and to deal more honestly with their clients.
Debate (on motion by Mr Melham) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND GRANT AND MANAGEMENT (JERVIS BAY TERRITORY) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to the debate upon the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 before the House today. The bill, as outlined in the second reading speech by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, the Hon. Robert Tickner, arises from negotiations between the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community and the Commonwealth, as part of the implementation of recommendations made by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

PARA.TAB: Since its election in 1983, the Labor government has radically transformed the landscape of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in this nation. In so doing, we have effectively raised policy issues pertaining to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people from a 10th order issue under the Fraser coalition government to a first order issue under the Keating Labor government. The government's commitment to a socially just society—where all Australians, regardless of their race, sex or colour, are able to achieve their full potential and participate equally as citizens in a multicultural society—forms the building block upon which this government has formulated Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy.

A key initiative in this government's efforts to deal with the multitude of issues pertaining to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people has been the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody which, with the full support of the state and territory governments, reported in 1991. The report handed down by the commission covered a wide range of enormously complex issues dealing with the underlying causes relating to the excessive number of Aboriginal deaths in custody. In so doing, the commission made 339 recommendations which, in their implementation, traverse legislative and administrative spheres of the three tiers of government in Australia.

To this end, the legislation before the House today seeks to amend the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973, to facilitate the attainment of recommendation 315 of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which I have already mentioned. In this context, recommendation 315—also known as the `Millstream' recommendation, framed by the Aboriginal delegates to a 1990 conference in the Millstream-Chester National Park—deals specifically with initiatives to protect and reserve the rights and interests of Aboriginal people with cultural, historical and traditional associations with national parks.

The key initiatives outlined under recommendation 315 include the encouragement of joint management between identified and acknowledged representatives of Aboriginal people and the relevant state or national agency; the involvement of Aboriginal people in the development of management plans for national parks; the excision of areas of land within national parks for use by Aboriginal people as living areas; the granting of access by Aboriginal people to national parks and national reserves for subsistence hunting, fishing and collection of material for cultural purposes; and the facilitation of the control of cultural heritage information by Aboriginal people.

The key initiatives also include the negotiation of lease-back arrangements which enable title to land on which national parks are situated to be transferred to Aboriginal owners, subject to the lease of the area to the relevant state or Commonwealth authority on payment of rent to the Aboriginal owners; the reservation within national parks of areas of land to which Aboriginal people have access for ceremonial purposes; the establishment of mechanisms which enable relevant Aboriginal custodians to be in control of protection of, and access to, sites of significance to them; and the charging of admission fees for entrance to national parks by tourists.

The amendments outlined in the bill before the House today put into effect the key initiatives of recommendation 315 and reflect the government's position as a pacesetter in dealing with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy issues derived from the royal commission report. Indeed, similar initiatives relating to Aboriginal community land management and lease-back arrangements already exist within the Kakadu and Uluru national parks. In this context, this bill builds upon the foundation that has already been laid by the successful implementation of lease-back and land management arrangements at Kakadu and Uluru in order to facilitate a similar success within the confines of the Jervis Bay territory.

All available historical research evidence indicates that there have been Aboriginal settlements in Jervis Bay for at least 20,000 years. In this context, Wreck Bay, which is located within the confines of the Jervis Bay territory, has been the focal point of Aboriginal settlement for much of the last century. In the 1950s, the area of land which the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community had been inhabiting in an informal reserve type arrangement was formally gazetted as a reserve and in l965 the area was transferred to the control of the then Commonwealth Department of the Interior. After the majority of the Jervis Bay territory was proclaimed a nature reserve in 1971, the federal Labor government in l986 granted some 405 hectares as freehold title to the Wreck Bay community under the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act.

In granting the freehold title to the Aboriginal community at Wreck Bay, the government, under the act, established a community council to exercise powers as owners of the land for the benefit of the members of the community. In this context, I would submit that to date these arrangements have seen the Wreck Bay community council operate as a model community, which will no doubt be reflected in the future land management aspects of the bill before us today.

At this point I would like to turn to the key amendments specifically outlined in the bill before the Main Committee today, and to draw out the implications that will flow from the future enactment of the bill. In this context, the foundations upon which the strategic direction of the bill rests can be seen in the amendments to the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986.

The amendments pertaining to the 1986 act will enable the national park and the botanic gardens which are within the confines of the park to be granted to the Wreck Bay community council. Such a grant of land would be subject to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs being satisfied of the significance of the area to the Aboriginal community and entry into a formal agreement to lease the land back to the director of National Parks and Wildlife Service. Further to this, the community council will be empowered to make by-laws with respect to the land granted to them.

The amendments relating to the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986 meet a number of the key initiatives of recommendation 315 of the royal commission. In this context, the negotiation of a lease-back arrangement with the director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service—when combined with the community council by-laws power which allows Aboriginal people to deal with issues such as the protection and conservation of flora and fauna found on Aboriginal land, the declaration of sacred or significant sites on other areas of significance to Aboriginal people on Aboriginal land, hunting, shooting and fishing on Aboriginal land, control of visitors in, and charging fees for entrance to, Aboriginal land, and economic enterprise and cultural activities on Aboriginal land—provides a number of the mechanisms required to facilitate the successful implementation of recommendation 315.

The by-laws outlined above certainly provide the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community with significant control of their ancestral lands and in this context provide a sound basis to address the underlying causes outlined in the royal commission and the reconciliation issues being pursued by the federal government.

In terms of the arrangements to lease back the land encompassed by the national park and the botanic gardens, this amendment forms the basis of the cooperative land management arrangements between the Wreck Bay community council and the director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which were again highlighted in recommendation 315 of the royal commission, to which I have already referred.

The arrangements will ensure that broad community access to the national park will be maintained and that any person's existing legal right or interest in land granted to the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community will also be maintained. The lease-back arrangements outlined above tie into the second major raft of amendments which pertain to the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1975. In this context, the amendments are designed to enable the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council to participate in the management of the Jervis Bay National Park and Botanical Gardens if they are declared to be Aboriginal land under the Aboriginal Land Grant (Jervis Bay Territory) Act 1986.

This reflects the government's and the vast majority of the Aboriginal community's view that Aboriginal participation in the management and control of the conservation estate is fundamental to the acknowledgment of Aboriginal rights to land and the control of Aboriginal cultural heritage.

To facilitate the joint management of these areas which may be declared to be Aboriginal land, the National Parks and Wildlife Act 1975 provides for the establishment of boards along the lines of those already in operation in the Uluru and Kakadu national parks. To this end, once land in the Jervis Bay National Park and Botanic Gardens is declared to be Aboriginal land, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) may establish a board for those areas once agreement is reached with the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council.

The board, which is established for the Jervis Bay National Park land, will comprise the majority of Aboriginal members nominated by the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land. In concert with the director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the board will develop a management plan for the park which will encompass a range of issues, including access, conservation, fire protection and the development and use of Aboriginal land. In this context, the board, in conjunction with the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council, will effectively utilise the skills and experience that the Aboriginal peoples have developed over time in the conservation and maintenance of natural resources and native flora and fauna in the Jervis Bay ecosystem.

The federal government has set the pace when it comes to the development of viable land management arrangements between the traditional Aboriginal owners of land in national parks and reserves and the agencies charged under the Commonwealth legislation to effectively manage these lands. In this context, the Commonwealth, with the enactment of this legislation which is before us today, will have effectively laid the groundwork to hand over the last of the major national park and reserve lands to their traditional Aboriginal owners through the lease-back and land management arrangements that I have already outlined.

Subsequently, the ball will be in the court of the various state and territory governments who have parks and reserves which Aboriginal people have claims to in terms of entering into arrangements to provide for the joint management and lease-back of this land. I certainly hope that the states and territories will take up that challenge.

I now turn my attention to the last of the major amendments of this bill which pertain to the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973. These amendments will enable the Commonwealth Grants Commission to inquire into grants for financial assistance, in terms of works and services, in respect of the Jervis Bay territory, amongst others. The inquiries made by the Commonwealth Grants Commission, which, in turn, reports its findings to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, will not only assist in the development of appropriate facilities and services for the joint management of the land, but also facilitate efforts to further develop the commercial aspects of the park in a way which will not harm the fragile ecosystem and will benefit the Aboriginal community.

In this context, the Wreck Bay Aboriginal Community Council, if it so desires, will be able to develop the ecotourism and cultural tourism potential of the Jervis Bay National Park. Access to funding for specific projects through the Department of Tourism and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will also be a major benefit. The potential to generate income and business opportunities through the marketing of the area as a cultural tourism destination will have real benefits for the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community in terms of employment opportunities for Aboriginal people and the development of particular management skills associated with the tourism industry and associated businesses. And the revenue generated by the council could be ploughed back into the development of infrastructure and services which have been identified as being of benefit to the Aboriginal communities.

To sum up, the bill which is before the House today reflects this government's commitment to the implementation of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody as part of its overall strategy of ensuring Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander equity and reconciliation objectives. In this context, the bill before us today covers a large portion of the initiatives outlined under recommendation 315 of the royal commission report. In so doing, it addresses some of the underlying factors behind the excessive numbers of Aboriginal people who die in custody and, unfortunately, who are still dying in custody today.

Let me emphasise that, while this bill is a step in the right direction, there is still much that needs to be done, not only in the implementation of the recommendations of the royal commission but also in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues more generally, right across this nation. Of course, it is the responsibility of us, as members of this parliament, to ensure that much more progress is made in that area.

The government, of course, recognises the enormity of the issues that confront it in this area, but we are determined to provide the innovative legislative responses needed to combat the problems. In this context, I commend the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said, the Aboriginal Land Grant and Management (Jervis Bay Territory) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 before the House deals with the granting of land which is already primarily a national park to a group known as the Wreck Bay Aboriginal community. It does so for the purpose of giving them an involvement in land with which they have had a close association for many years. The extent to which that is a tribal association is, from my recollection, probably more expanded today than it was at the time when some original grants were made down in that area to the people who had resided there for many years.

PARA.TAB: I will stand corrected by the next speaker, the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) as to the chronology of this issue, but I have a feeling that possibly the original grant was made when the Fraser government was still in office. I say that because I recollect discussing the issue. It was the first time, in the context of that grant, that I raised the question as to why we had to provide such people with inalienable freehold title, when it struck me that ordinary Australian title might have been more appropriate, since they were people who were going to live in houses on that property and it would appear to me that they should have had some right to buy and sell those houses.

This case is slightly different, because we are talking about an area designated as a national park, but I have stuck to the view—and I will continue to stick to it—that it is gross paternalism for us to say in one breath that the Aboriginal people have very close links with the land with which they have been associated and that they could not be trusted to keep that ownership if they were given the normal sort of title. We stand up here as a paternalistic group and say, `We will give you a title that you cannot deal in, borrow against or even move from.' I find that totally illogical when one considers the arguments as to why they should have the land in the first place, and I take every opportunity to put on record that I do not see it as a process that assists the people concerned.

The other little bit of history relates to the creation of the national park itself. Of course, the people of the area were rather sorely treated, because they had, to the best of my knowledge, quite properly used the beaches and the fishing spots of Jervis Bay for many years as an area of recreation; but, when it was declared a national park, the first thing we did was put up some boom gates and start taking money for the privilege of using the area. We never thought that the locals might have some rights, similar to those granted by local authorities, to a couple of free visits to the tip. I hope they were never using the park for that purpose, but the point is that, when we converted that land to a national park, people who lived within a reasonable distance and who had traditionally used it—and I stress those word `traditionally'—for their recreational swimming, sunbaking or fishing should have had some free access to it.

For quite some time, the people vented their anger on that arrangement by going out and smashing the windows of the entrance fee booths. If you travel there today, you will find steel shutters on all the booths. People were not very happy with what had been done. That is not an Aboriginal issue; that was because the area was made a national park and the traditional users of that area were denied the access to which they had been accustomed. But, of course, they were different people: they were just the taxpaying citizens of Australia, and we normally do not have a lot of care for them. I think that is worth putting on the record.

I am interested in this particular legislation because, as we have been advised, it follows the process that applied at Uluru, and that has proved quite successful. It does not suggest there is a lease payment—and I assume that is correct. Again, the parliamentary secretary or somebody else might like to tell me whether, in this process of granting the land to the Aboriginal people in the peculiar form of title that we have created, with the condition that they lease it back, there is any fee for that process—be it weekly, annually or lump sum. I am interested to know if that applies because it then talks about their rights to gain royalties from allowing timber cutting concessions. I am surprised about that. I did not think there would be much of that available but, irrespective of that, there is a focus on the community group obtaining revenue from this proposal. I do not object to that either. I just wanted to take the opportunity to talk a little bit about how such revenue might be used.

Clearly, in the case of this park, it would not be a significant sum of money, presumably, even in terms of the revenue that one might get from concessions of the nature referred to. But I note in the second reading speech that the council is to be given the power to enter into contracts involving payments by the council of up to $100,000 without the approval of the minister. That is not necessarily wrong either but somewhere or other there is substantial revenue involved in this process. I am assuming that the type of contract that might be let would improve the value of this national park. Whether that would be by cutting down some trees to build another road, I am not really sure.

The reality of it is that that would be an expenditure on the park, on the property, and one would have expected that the lessee—in this case the National Parks and Wildlife Service—would have been more inclined to those sorts of outlays. I understood that that sort of property improvement is more likely to emanate from that area, so I am not really sure what that is all about.

The reason I want to raise the question of revenue emanating from such facilities is that the minister also makes some reference in his second reading speech to some aspects of this legislation that parallel that which applies to the Northern Land Council. I do not think there is much doubt that the Northern Land Council receives substantial revenues from the Gove manganese mining operation, et cetera. For years I have been trying to find out how it spends that money because it is in the tens of millions. It is a body that does not publish a balance sheet but prepares a balance sheet, and no doubt is subject to some audit process. I think it does report to the minister. Our next speaker might be able to enlighten us because he was the minister at one time.

The Central Land Council for a number of years, on a much smaller revenue, something like about $4 million, used to publish its balance sheet. It was quite interesting because, year after year, the $4 million was spent. I could never identify any capital asset that was constructed with the money. In fact, most of it seemed to be spent on attending meetings. I would have thought—and this is the point I want to make—that where there is significant revenue coming from these grants of land it would normally in the wider community be the revenue of government, which would apply it to its hospital, education and other programs of that nature. I think we are entitled to know in this parliament where such revenue is expended.

If the money improves the amenity of a national park and its attraction to the public, that is a proper way to spend the money. If it creates wages for some of the participants, that is a proper way to spend the money. In the context of this particular legislation, that would probably be the end of it. When it is mining royalties and revenue such as the Northern Land Council gets I think there is an obligation on us as members of parliament to clearly bring a budget to the parliament so people can see and understand how that money is expended.

In terms of these grants of land rights and the income that might flow from that particular land-holding by way of royalty, there should be a clear commitment that the community will know how that money is being spent. There should be a role for government, having granted and conceded that right to a land council—a right that would otherwise create revenue for government—in giving some indication as to how the money might be expended in terms of lifting the living standards of the tribal group.

We are assailed in this parliament, day after day, about the problem of the health condition of Aboriginal people, and the Minister for Education, Employment and Training (Mr Crean) tells us about the dreadful state of Aboriginal education. I do not disagree that both of those statements of problems are correct, but they should not be a problem for the participants of the Northern Land Council, because they have tens of millions of dollars of revenue, and one would think that—with community ownership of land, land rights, and the right to levy royalties—they would not have that problem for their people.

It does not have to go beyond their people, because there is not all that much money, and I say it is a tribal right because it is tribal land. But because there is a royalty base and, in any other situation, that royalty would flow to government, who would choose to direct some of it back into all these areas, there is a responsibility on the managers of that money to spend it in that way. From my observations of the living standards of the people whom they represent, they do not spend it in that way, and I am not sure how they do spend it.

When I was a member of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and we conducted certain inquiries, we ended up in Broome on one occasion, and the manager of a particular station property that was now Aboriginal land came to give us evidence. He was an Australian, but of European background, and he made the point that it was a profitable station, but that he could not get the owners to work on it. It is on the record somewhere from the time, because he gave evidence to our committee that, when he needed to muster and do other things, he had to go off the property to hire people to assist him in the conduct of the property. That is a tragedy, amongst other things, but it is also wrong, because—to use his words—the proprietors of that property preferred `sit-down money'.

I do not say that you could have a very large community living on one pastoral property and that they could all get a living out of it, because they could not. We know that, in this day and age, a normal single family unit has difficulty making sufficient profits out of some of these properties to sustain themselves, but that is after they have paid wages. It would seem ridiculous that people would be brought in to work on that property when the owners were not working and were, in fact, in receipt of unemployment benefits.

That was a matter of evidence given to us at the time, and I really and truly think that, whether in this particular situation at Jervis Bay or the Northern Land Council—which probably gets more revenue than any other land council or similar body in Australia—there should be an accounting, and there should be an expectation that a substantial part of that revenue be paid out to improve those fundamental requirements relating to Aboriginal people: schooling, education, health and those types of things.

I certainly did not gather that impression from the opportunity I once had but which I think is now denied me: I have not seen a published balance sheet of the Central Land Council for many years. But, for a long time, to their credit, they published it. They had at the time revenue of about $4 million dollars. I have never seen a balance sheet for the Northern Land Council. I know there are some people involved in that council who seem to have substantial trappings of wealth. That in itself is not a problem, as I do not see why they have to be poor, if they are the chief executive or the chairman or whatever else of that particular organisation. But, as a member of parliament, I would like to be guaranteed that when we make these grants and there is a revenue component—which I hope there is, because I do not think it is much good giving them desert and telling them that because they once lived there they should go back, because that is not the way our society operates today—it should be used well.

I just feel that we do need to see that substantial revenue streams which would otherwise be the property of government, be it state, federal or local, and would be spent in community development, should be done similarly but for the discrete group of people whose rights that land is for. You might jump and say that if you have got a pastoral property and it is freehold you can spend the money how you like. Pastoral property is not freehold, but let us say you have a large freehold farm: you can spend the money how you like. That is partially true, but the first thing that most people tend to do is pay private health insurance and they go out and pay to send their kids to school. They even contribute when they go to a state school. They certainly do not get their shoes bought for them and their clothes bought for them.

There is nothing wrong with requiring, or expecting, that that money, that revenue stream that flows into these communities because of these land grants, is used in a way that lifts the living standard of these people, and I think it amazing that within that Northern Land Council, with such substantial revenue streams—much bigger than most local authorities—there does not appear to be any improvement in the general living standards of the people involved. I think some of the people on Groote Eylandt, where they have their rights, are better off in terms of such things as motor cars and things of that nature. I have had recent reports emanating from the Kimberley of young people, and I mean juveniles, walking around with $3,000 and $4,000 in their pocket, and that is just heart-breaking if that is all that is being done with it. I am not saying this is the case, but I would find it tragic to think you had some kid sniffing on petrol with $1,000 in his pocket. I just do not think we are arriving at a solution.

In the few minutes I have got left, I want to raise another issue of grave concern, the attempts of the federal government to intrude in an area of state administration, namely, the granting of land, and the consequent manoeuvrings illegally by which they have attempted to get around the constitutional issues, notwithstanding the views of the High Court on that. The legislation might be constitutional but it is so convoluted that it is now creating great administrative difficulty, and that was identified at the time by more reasonable commentators. The reality is that Aboriginals are not getting anything, business and those wishing to develop are getting very little, and I doubt there is anything that can be done of a legislative and constitutional nature in this place to fix it up because we lack the constitutional power, particularly as the constitution is so specific about the Commonwealth's role in land administration, where it says that if you want to do anything about land you must buy it.

I visited Broome in my role as shadow minister for veterans' affairs when we recognised the death of 70 and probably many more Australian citizens during a Japanese air raid on Broome. I spent time going out into the bay there with one of the leading citizens of Broome, a shire councillor. He tells me that the situation for local government administration there has become intolerable simply because of a land claim over every unalienated piece of land in the Broome shire, and more particularly the town site, where they have got little parks and gardens.

They now have a representative of the Aboriginal group making these claims—I do not know if he is an Aboriginal or a white lawyer—who not only comes into the council meetings but who sits at the table with the democratically elected councillors to tell them what decisions they might make. For instance, the other day they had an application from Rotary to put two gas barbecues on a piece of parkland within the town site and this guy vetoed it. One might wonder why; it was just a straight-out amenity. I bring it to the parliament's attention. I am not trying to score points; it is a fact of life. I put it down as an issue that has got to be resolved. I do not think the federal parliament can resolve these issues.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.20 p.m. to 12.37 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the speech made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The speech could be summed up in terms of a view that is continually expressed by the member for O'Connor. It is not that the member for O'Connor lacks sympathy; it is just that he thinks that, if Aboriginal people thought the way we do and adopted the same material and mental standards, then there would be no problem. Therein lies the difference between the member for O'Connor and members on this side. If we have learnt anything over 200 years, it ought to be simply that Aboriginal people have a view of themselves, their family, this land and their relationship with their land which does not rest on the individual property concepts which are very much a part of our culture.

PARA.TAB: I was the minister who had the responsibility for negotiating the first grant of land back to the Wreck Bay community and it was not a simple process. Two very distinguished ministers during the period of the Fraser government—Mr Ian Viner and Mr Fred Chaney—had previously tried and they were unsuccessful. They were unsuccessful largely because of the amount of land which was involved and because, basically, as ministers for Aboriginal affairs, they were not able to negotiate with the Minister for Lands and Territories to assure the size of the area of land that was offered.

I was fortunate in as much as I had as a minister Tom Uren and Tom Uren had a generosity of spirit and an attitude towards Aboriginal people which gave me a greater freedom. But these negotiations were complex—I do not know whether the honourable member for O'Connor has ever been to Wreck Bay—because even then the Wreck Bay community felt that they were not getting enough land.
